questions.question: What is the 'optimal pH' for an enzyme?
options: The pH at which the enzyme works fastest
The most acidic pH the enzyme can survive
The pH of pure water (pH 7)
The pH that destroys the enzyme completely
questions.explanation: The optimal pH is the pH level where the enzyme catalyzes reactions at its maximum rate - it's the peak of the enzyme activity graph.

questions.question: What happens to enzymes in very acidic or very basic conditions?
options: They can denature and lose their specific shape
They work faster because pH provides extra energy
They become permanently activated to work at any pH
They break down into simple sugars and fats
questions.explanation: Extreme pH levels can disrupt the bonds that hold the enzyme's 3D shape, causing it to unravel (denature) and lose function, similar to high temperatures.

questions.question: Which enzyme works best in the acidic environment of the stomach?
options: Pepsin (optimal pH around 2)
Salivary amylase (optimal pH around 7)
Trypsin (optimal pH around 8)
Pancreatic lipase (optimal pH around 7)
questions.explanation: Pepsin, the stomach enzyme that digests proteins, works best at very acidic pH (around pH 2), which matches the stomach's hydrochloric acid environment.

questions.question: Why do most enzymes in human cells work best around neutral pH (6-8)?
options: That's the pH of most body fluids and cell cytoplasm
Neutral pH is the only pH where enzymes can work
Acidic and basic conditions don't exist in living things
All enzymes in nature have evolved for pH 7
questions.explanation: Most human cells maintain a near-neutral internal environment (pH around 7.2-7.4), so their enzymes have evolved to work best at that pH.

questions.question: What would a graph of enzyme activity vs. pH typically look like?
options: A curve that rises to a peak then drops on both sides
A straight line going upward as pH increases
A flat line that doesn't change with pH
A zigzag pattern with many peaks and valleys
questions.explanation: Like the temperature graph, pH graphs usually show a bell-shaped curve: activity increases to optimal pH, then decreases as pH becomes too acidic or too basic.

questions.question: How does pH affect the charges on amino acids in an enzyme?
options: It changes which amino acids are positively or negatively charged
It removes all charges from the amino acids
It adds extra phosphate groups to the amino acids
It has no effect on amino acid charges
questions.explanation: pH affects whether acidic amino acids (like aspartic acid) are charged (-) or neutral, and whether basic amino acids (like lysine) are charged (+) or neutral, changing how they interact.

questions.question: Why does changing the charges on amino acids affect enzyme function?
options: Correct charges help maintain the enzyme's shape and active site
Charges provide the energy needed for catalysis
Enzymes need maximum charge to work properly
All enzymes must be completely neutral to function
questions.explanation: The specific 3D shape of enzymes depends on attractions and repulsions between charged amino acids. Wrong charges mean wrong shape, so the active site doesn't work properly.

questions.question: What happens when you add antacid medication for heartburn?
options: It raises stomach pH, temporarily reducing pepsin activity
It lowers stomach pH, speeding up all digestion
It denatures all enzymes in the digestive system
It provides extra enzymes to help with digestion
questions.explanation: Antacids neutralize stomach acid, raising pH. This temporarily reduces pepsin activity (which needs acidic pH), relieving discomfort from excess stomach acid.

questions.question: Which enzyme would likely work best in the basic (alkaline) small intestine?
options: Trypsin (optimal pH around 8)
Pepsin (optimal pH around 2)
Salivary amylase (optimal pH around 7)
All enzymes work the same at any pH
questions.explanation: Trypsin, a pancreatic enzyme that continues protein digestion, works best around pH 8, matching the slightly basic environment of the small intestine where bicarbonate neutralizes stomach acid.

questions.question: How are pH effects similar to temperature effects on enzymes?
options: Both show optimal ranges with bell-shaped activity curves
Both always increase enzyme activity when increased
Neither has any permanent effect on enzyme structure
Both effects are exactly the same for all enzymes
questions.explanation: Both temperature and pH graphs typically show bell curves with optimal points. Both can denature enzymes at extremes, and different enzymes have different optimal ranges for both factors.
